headline: Kung Pao Chicken
description: Love kung pao chicken? It's easy to make this restaurant favorite at home with this tasty recipe that's easy to adjust to the spice level you like.

video.description: Make spicy kung pao chicken that rivals your favorite Chinese restaurantâ€™s version.
video.name: Kung Pao Chicken

name: Kung Pao Chicken
recipeIngredient: 2 tablespoons cornstarch, dissolved in 2 tablespoons water
1 pound skinless, boneless chicken breast halves - cut into chunks

recipeInstructions.text: Combine water and cornstarch in a cup; set aside.

Combine 1 tablespoon wine, 1 tablespoon soy sauce, 1 tablespoon sesame oil, and 1 tablespoon cornstarch/water mixture in a large glass bowl. Add chicken pieces and toss to coat. Cover the dish and refrigerate for about 30 minutes.

Combine remaining 1 tablespoon wine, 1 tablespoon soy sauce, 1 tablespoon sesame oil, and remaining cornstarch/water mixture in a medium bowl. Whisk in chile paste, brown sugar, and vinegar. Add water chestnuts, peanuts, green onions, and garlic and toss to coat.
Transfer water chestnut mixture to a medium skillet. Heat slowly over medium heat until aromatic.
Meanwhile, transfer chicken from marinade into a large skillet; cook over medium-high heat, stirring, until chicken is cooked through and juices run clear.
Combine water chestnut mixture and sautÃ©ed chicken together in one skillet. Adjust heat and simmer together until sauce thickens.

review.reviewBody: This was fantastic. Like other reviewers said, I doubled all the ingredients except the Chicken. I had a little over a pound of chicken for the 2 of us and it was great so Jeff had leftovers for his lunch. I didn't have enough peanuts so I used 1/2 almonds. Jeff wished I used cashews. I also didn't have water chestnuts so I used some snap peas and red peppers. But I added those veggies at the VERY end so they didn't get soggy. Next time I will use rice vinegar for more flavor. I didn't know how much an ounce of chili paste was so i used 2 big tablespoons of it. I cooked it in a cast iron pan which stuck at first but then I added more clean crafted wine and water too. So delicious!
I followed the recipe to the letter. I used Thai chili paste, first time using the ingredient it was so fragrant and delicious!!!
I followed the recipe exactly and it had no flavor. There was no sauce at all but more of a pasty goo.

I have to agree with many others on this site. No flavor. Much too pasty, thick. My husband ate it and said it was good, but I think he just didn't want to make me feel bad. I had gone to a lot of trouble putting this together while suffering terrible back pain. I was sorry I didn't get carryout instead. I threw the recipe in the trash. Definitely not a keeper!
I think marinating the chicken overnight instead of 30 mins would give it more flavor. All in all my family enjoyed it ðŸ˜Š

this is nothibg like chinatown kunc pao. i've had it in LA,SF and Portland Ore. always more vegetables than meat. no brochli. lots of garlic ginger abd rice wine vinnegar. 3 stars is generous in my opinion.
Easy to make and amazing flavors. Preparation is everything as there is a lot of chopping. I added celery and a touch of ginger. Nice touch.
Great flavor overall, will add some more red pepper flakes to bring a little kick. It was easy, served over rice.
Added some mushrooms, broccoli and celery. Used gochujang as the pepper paste. Turned out really good
Triple the sauce but not the peanuts or water chestnuts. If you substitute Sriracha for chili paste don't triple it either, it will over power the dish.
indian peanuts go grab too, very good dish
This is a great recipe. I follow it exactly and double the sauce.
I followed the recipe, except I used leg meat instead of breast. I found that the recipe lacked and adequate amount of sauce. I will increase the ingredients, if I make it again.
I made this exactly as directed, except had to add more water. It was awful. No flavor, a complete waste of time and ingredients.

I mainly came here for the sauce and it was great. Like others, doubled the sauce for a pound of chicken and glad I did. I did find it was too much cornstarch because I continually needed to keep adding water as I heated it. I did swap out white wine for Shaosing Rice cooking Wine but that is just preference. I Wok fried my chicken first (then removed), then some white onions and two zucchini, skipped the chestnuts. Added it back together and then added sauce. Very versatile sauce that is a great starting point for your chicken and choice of vegetables. I suggest tasting it as you go, try to find the perfect sweet, sour and spice for your taste buds.

Delish! I altered the recipe to suit my tastes. Used chicken instead of shrimp, left off the peanuts, and substituted packaged stir-fry vegetables (which I steamed in the microwave). Turned out very well!

OMG! I finally know how to make my favorite Chinese takeout dish. I used combination of dark and light soy sauce, and shaoxing cooking wine instead of white wine just because I had a big bottle of it from another recipe I tried. This recipe is definitely a keeper. I didnâ€™t know what chili paste the recipe was referring to, so I used half a teaspoon of the fried chili in oil I had and the dried red whole chilies for aroma. I had my friend who is a foodie when it comes to Asian cuisine, and she agreed it tasted like the takeout minus and guilt of consuming too much sodium.
4 T white wine, 4 T soy sauce, 4 t brown sugar, sliced celery instead of water chestnuts, 1/2 chopped red pepper, 1 carrot peeled and grated
This turned out very good! I did not have white wine and I was not going to spend the
Very good. Made it with minimal alterations, simply left out the brown sugar and tripled sauce for extra veggies. Will definitely make again, and again.

Had to modify due to ingredients available. Added broccoli and large chunks of sweet onion. Deleted water chestnuts. Used 1 tablespoon molasses instead of brown sugar. Deleted white wine. Turned out very well despite substitution. Molasses was a good call and I will be using it going on for this type of dish.
Not our favorite. The vinegar was a predominant flavor. Flavors just did not â€œmeldâ€ better Asian style recipes on this website!

I made this adding red bell pepper and chopped onion (didnâ€™t have green onions) because thatâ€™s what our favorite Chinese restaurant does. I also had to substitute Garlic Chili Sauce for the Chili Paste. It had great taste and next time Iâ€™ll add some chicken broth and increase the corn starch to increase the volume of sauce.
I made as directed except I made more sauce. Very good. Kids liked it.
Insufficient liquid for cornstarch. I had to add water to make the sauce suitable consistency and amount for the chicken.
We prepared this dish as written but we found it very blah. Very uninteresting so we wonâ€™t be making it again.
This is the best Kung Pow recipe I have ever made... the only difference is that I added stir fried red pepper and zucchini, just to get a few more vegetables into my husband.

I added broccoli, scallions, green pepper, and lightly salted dry roasted peanuts and it was amazing! Kung Pao Chicken is a carry out favorite from the local Chinese restaurant, but theyâ€™ve got serious competition! This was BETTER than carry out! Served over white rice, it is delicious!
did not change a thing - delicious!

We all loved this. I quadrupled the recipe and used chicken thighs. Went light on the sugar and oil, no cornstarch in the marinade, and went light on cornstarch in the sauce and still had to add water. Taste was authentic and I lived in Asia for 13 years so have a pretty good use of what Chinese food should taste like. Will definitely make again.

I thought this was pretty good. I used thighs and cooked them on an electric griddle-which I can get screaming hot. I think there was too much corn starch in the sauce as I had to add water to thin out. Otherwise very good flavor. Definitely a keeper. Thank you!!

It was yummy and fresh tasting. Added diced carrots, mushrooms and celery to the dish to have more veg. Recommend either doubling sauce or making single batch of sauce and adding 1 cup chicken broth to the sauce so there is enough sauce for the rice. 

We used rice wine vinegar and sirachi sauce as substitutes
Flavor is indeed restaurant quality. I added bell peppers for color and texture. Also, I would increase the sauce 1.5x next time. My preference.

I really liked it & I believe the Chinese reviewers who say itâ€™s authentic. For those who said the chicken was dry, I say good. I hate soft squishy rubbery chicken. I like chicken to be dry & chewy. Juicy doesnâ€™t work for me in this recipe. Itâ€™s already â€œjuicyâ€ enough.
Followed exactly as written and tasted great!
Great Kung pao chicken recipe! Sauce amount was perfect, I did add some extra chili peppers to make it spicy. Family loved it, definitely make it again!

Delicious! The only ingredient I changed was using rice vinegar in place of the white wine. I also took the advice of many reviewers and doubled the sauce amount. Better than the local restaurant versions!
This was delicious!!! Next time, I plan on making more of the sauce. There wasn't enough in my opinion.
Very little flavor.

Very good. I added 2 celery sticks, a small red pepper and a small yellow pepper for color and crunch. It was delicious. I served it with sticky white rice and an egg roll. It did take longer got me to prepare than time given but that was okay. It is worth the extra time needed.
Loved the recipe! It was easy to find gluten and dairy free products for this recipe! Added broccoli and laid recipe over Botan Rice! Omg kids and husband loved it!!! Thanks for sharing!

This was a great inspiration to change up dinner ideas using our limited supplies during the virus outbreak. We were able to have one of our favorite meals and it really boosted everyone's spirit. I had to use frozen mixed veggies but it still came out great. Thanks so much for sharing!
Great recipe! I doubled the sauce and added broccoli instead of the water chestnuts since that is what I had on hand. Served with fried rice. It was big hit with my family and we will make again!

Used salted peanuts, so I skipped salting my rice. In the end, I added some salt back in after it was plated. Didn't know what 1 oz of chili paste was, so I did 1 Tbsp - ended up adding some sriracha after serving. Could have used more texture, maybe wait to add onion and peanuts until the very end.
Nailed it never follow the recipe exactly. I had a quite a bit more soy sauce. And triple the sauce amount?
Receipt was / is great, quick and easy! We doubled the chili paste for little extra kick.

We made this dish tonight and it was delicious! Hereâ€™s the only things I did different: 1. Salt and pepper the chicken before putting in marinade 2. Double the sauce at you will need it,it cooks down fast with the corn starch 3. My husband accidentally bought diced water chestnuts, but they turned out perfect in this dish! Enjoy itâ€™s a keeper....our picky eater had seconds!
My family loved this!!!

This was a hit with my family! I combined the marinade and sauce (as written, minus the cornstarch), then doubled that and added a 1/4 tsp of ginger. Marinaded the chicken for 3 hours. Stir fried carrots, green pepper and green onions, but left out water chestnuts. Sauteed the chicken without the sauce, then mixed with the vegetables, added the marinade/sauce and 1TBL cornstarch mixed with 1/2 c water. Served with sticky rice.
I incorporated others' suggestions to increase the sauce amount (by 5 times!!) and reduce the oil and corn starch. I also used hot sesame oil and sambal olek chili paste. Delicious!
I like to assemble marinade meals and pop them in the freezer. This is by far the best Iâ€™ve tried. No subs, no other things added..perfect the way it was. Thank you!

Amazing !!! Easy and authentic !! Definitely double the marinade and double or triple the sauce. Use shaoxing cooking wine, rice vinegar and sambal chili paste. All easily found in the asian aisle and absolutely adds to the authenticity. Low sodium/lite soy also recommended so salt isn't overpowering. Apart from those minor suggestions prepare per recipe. They will be fighting for leftovers !!
My wife loved this when I made it....the only thing I added was salt a Szechuan pepper. She wants me to make it again real soon.

As written, this is a good Kung Pao. To make it 5 stars, I use the sauce (minus the cornstarch) as marinade and "soak" for 24 hours, giving it a good shake every once in a while. You can still use the sauce (make sure to add the cornstarch here), just make sure during the heating process, you reach a boiling point and you will probably want to boil for 5 minutes (keep stirring so it doesn't burn). Or, you can make new sauce. I have used the marinade as the sauce several times with no problem.
I substituted chicken broth for the wine- delicious!

Not a fan of water chestnuts, but couldn't find bamboo shoots 
Still - yummy

I added 4 cloves garlic, 3 spears celery, 1.5 zucchiniâ€™s and stir fried. For the sauce used Sirachi as I didnâ€™t have chili paste, and just used vegetable oil as no sesame oil. Also doubled the sauce ingredients and baked the chicken separately and added on the side without marinade.Everyone liked...oh and added red pepper flakes for more pow.
I at least doubled all the ingredients plus threw in chopped serrano peppers for an extra punch of spice. I loved it, thanks for sharing this recipe!
Family loves it! Easy recipe to adjust for preferred taste.

This is a family favorite, with the change of doubling the sauce in the recipe...yet using only the two tbs. cornstarch. Broccoli, a shredded carrot, and mushrooms can be cooked separately as a side dish or added to the sauce toward the end of the cooking time. It is delicious and is incredibly close in flavor to the one that we get at one of our favorite local Chinese restaurants!
No changes to the recipe and it was absolutely delicious. One of the best meals Iâ€™ve had from an allrecipes recommendation.
I made this last night and it was delicious and easy to make. My family loved it. I just added red bell pepper for more color but it was great. I plan to make it again. Super easy meal.

Having cooked for over 50 years and not having eaten it yet, I would say this is a tasty recipe. There are actually 4 T. of liquids in the sauce, counting the oil. Later on, you can see that at least another quarter cup of water was added, so the result is not dry. It's a total of a half-cup of liquid. If the chicken itself turns out dry, you've over-cooked it. Chicken in small pieces takes only a few minutes to cook.
Delicious, really yummy!
This is a solid recipe for amazing Kung Pao Chicken. Instead of white vinegar I typically use Chinese dark vinegar for a richer flavor. I also like to throw in diced onion and bell pepper.
This was good!
Really bland, will look for a different recipe

This recipe was a big hit with my teenage daughter! I made it as only one serving for just her. I used 1 boneless skinless chicken breast (about 1/2 lb). I made the sauce and marinade with same proportions as the recipe calls for except I completely left out the chile paste (instead a minute sprinkling of red pepper flakes) and left out the water chestnuts. I substituted cashews & probably only used 2.5 - 3 oz. rather than the 4 oz that the recipe calls for. I marinated the chicken for probably close to 90 minutes. Served with jasmine rice and sautÃ©ed green beans. A GREAT meal! The amount of marinade and sauce that the recipe calls for was perfect for the 1/2 lb. of chicken.
Recipe was good and the dish was delicious! I will use half the peanuts next time and double the sauce.

This turned out very good! It was easy to make and taste was very close to restaurants version. I did make a few changes, I used carrots in place of water chestnuts which gave it a crunchy sweet taste to off set the spice. I used 1 tsp of corn starch in the marinade and 2 tsp in the sauce. I also used more garlic, about 4-5 tablespoons all together. We will be having this again!
easy to make and quite tasty. will try with cashews next time. might increase the sauce by half for the cooking portion. Delicious. Thanks for sharing.

I'm a kung pao fan but can't handle spicy food. I omitted the chili spice and it was really really good. I'm making this again! I bought a can of water chestnuts but forgot to add them. Didn't miss them though. 

The change I did was to sous vide the chicken chunks in the marinade. 149 degrees for 90 minutes. The chicken was sooo tender and able to cut it with a fork! I used the marinade from the sous vide bag and added brown sugar and vinegar to it in a separate skillet with the onion, garlic, and peanuts. The two sauces tasted pretty much the same but the one from the sous vide had a light brown color while the other one was dark reddish. I 4x the sauce ingredients and didn't need the extra sous vide sauce.
Very good, its a keeper!
I added lots of veggies and cooked it all together as recommended. Perfect.

I didn't hate it, but something was missing, and I'm not sure what it was. This was my first attempt at making any kung pao chicken. It was by far the best kung pao I've had since moving back to Idaho (my efforts to find good Chinese here is dismal). At first I thought more chili paste, but it had a decent hot kick to it. Maybe it was the reduced sodium soy sauce or maybe next time I will try more brown sugar (my daughter thought it lacked a slight sweetness). Either way there will be another try at this recipe. Thanks!

Iâ€™ve made this twice- this time I skipped marinade and doubled all sauce ingredients except garlic and chili paste and it was delicious and fast. I didnâ€™t miss the marinade. Still plenty garlicky and spicy hot. I will say the smell is more amazing than the taste - but still good. I only used chicken because my kids are picky- may need even more sauce if thereâ€™s veggies in there.
Edible, but not worth making again. Nothing like from a Chinese restaurant.

Very good! This is the second Asian dish that I'm making from All Recipes & I must admit so far so good. This Kung Pao Chicken got raving reviews from the family. I followed the recipe exactly and it was perfect. Wouldn't make any changes at all

ThIs was quite delicious. My husband enjoyed it and we eat at a lot of Chinese restaurants in California. I cant wait to make it for my son when he is home. i did have to add quite a bit more water to get it to the consistency I desired but that was fine. Definitely a keeper.

This was so tasty. I cooked some green bell and a jalapeno and sliced carrots prior to adding the sauce into the pan (I had to triple the sauce recipe due to veg. addition). I used chicken breast that I had baked and stored in the refrigerator...was so fast and easy. I skipped the peanuts. Love it!

Simply outstanding. The family wants this added to the rotation after dinner tonight.

Luckily I read the reviews and quadrupled the sauce. This is a must. Next time I'm cutting the starch from the marinade because that's just silly. And if you have a hungry family of four, you'd better double the recipe.

But this is seriously one of the best recipes I've ever found.
Like other reviewers, I tripled the sauce. I didnâ€™t reduce the sesame oil but made my own chili paste, which really ratchets up the heat.
Double, if not triple the sauce. Also I followed previous reviews and used rice wine. Itâ€™s a good base sauce and marinade that you can play with.
I added some onion and celery in place of the bamboo shoots. It was a hit at dinner tonight.
The only change I made was to use half of the hot chile paste. I still had a little heat and had a wonderful flavor. This is a keeper in our house. Thanks.

Really good! A few small changes that did not affect the overall recipe-just preference. I only added half the chili paste as we do not like our food that hot. I also used half the cornstarch which was plenty. I used more chicken so doubled the marinade and I stir fried red peppers, onion and pea pods and mixed with the sauce(quadrupled the sauce) and served on the side to add or not. My son gave it an A+. He does not hand those out very often!
uio
I loved the flavor of this recipe. Although I had to add water and chicken broth 'like the other reviewers, to thin out the sauce, the results were so good that I gave it 5 stars!!!!
This was fantastic. The only change was the addition of a 2 carrots cut up matchstick size. I cooked them with the chicken.

I followed the recipe as written but used chicken thighs instead of breasts. I also used Korean chili paste which has a little "sweet" to it. Next time I will cook the recipe in different order. I would add a little peanut or veg oil to the pan and cook the chicken on high heat until cooked as I learned when I lived in Japan.
I like the inclusion of the water chestnuts in this recipe. I think my local restaurants in my hometown when I was growing up never used it, but it really compliments this dish very well.
Delicious! Will make again!
Have to say that it was really good. Simple and best tasting stir fry that I have been able to make.
Made this exactly except doubled the sauce based on reviews. Wonderful!! Husband said to make this often. It is spicy but we love spicy, hot food.
Tasted great! I would probably double the marinade and sauce next time, but overall good flavor. Might add more spice to because I like my Kung Pao spicy!
It's good, but you need to double everything in the marinade and sauce except for the green onions and water chestnuts and peanuts. Yes that includes the chili paste.
this was a wonderful dinner highly recommend this dish no way to mess it up was delicious i recommend marinating for as long as u can very flavorful :)
this was a wonderful dinner highly recommend this dish no way to mess it up was delicious i recommend marinating for as long as u can very flavorful :)
I will make it again.
